and the AET is calculated as given by application of Formula (E.1):
AET (µg/ml) = {0,75 µg/d × [20 devices/(1 device/d × 33,3 ml)]} ÷ 2
AET (µg/ml) = 0,23 µg/ml
NOTE
Data establishing the actual release kinetics of leachables can be an essential input for establishing
an appropriately conservative DBT. If the actual release kinetics of leachables establishes that the exposure
to extractables is less than 10 years, then the kinetic data can potentially support a higher DBT value (see
ISO/TS 21726).
E.5	 Use of the AET
The conversion of the DBT to an AET enables an analytical chemist to address the question of whether
a specific extractable need be identified and quantified. However, analytical methods do not produce
concentrations directly but a response in units that should be converted to concentrations. For example,
the output of chromatographic analysis of a sample is a chromatogram in which extractables appear as
peaks in the chromatogram (see Figure E.1). In this case, peak A corresponds to an analyte present in
the test sample at a concentration equal to the AET. Thus, a horizontal AET line can be drawn across the
chromatogram using the apex of A as the reference point. Peaks whose responses fall above such a line
(e.g. peak B) are present in the sample at levels above the AET and the substance responsible for peak
B should be identified and reported for toxicological risk assessment. Peaks whose response fall below
the line (e.g. peak C) are present in the sample at levels below the AET and do not need to be identified
for toxicological risk assessment.
Figure E.1 — Application of the AET in chromatographic analysis
Although Figure  E.1 illustrates the application of the AET in terms of peak height, peak area may
also be used to compare individual extractables peaks with the AET and can be more appropriate.
Furthermore, while this example and illustration specifically relates to chromatographic analysis, the
concept of the AET is widely applicable to many analytical techniques.
E.6	 Exclusions to the AET; cohorts of concern
The term “cohorts of concern” has been applied to those sets of compounds that possess structural
groups of such high potency that intakes even below the TTC would be associated with a potential for
﻿
56 
© ISO 2020 – All rights reserved

ISO 10993-18:2020(E)
significant patient safety risk, including, but not necessarily limited to, carcinogenic risk. Compound
classes that comprise the cohorts of concern are described in ISO/TS 21726. Some colorants can also
have the potential to raise concern and should be considered for exclusion from the AET. See also
Reference [42] and ISO 10993-17.
The previously established convention that extractables below the AET are taken to be toxicologically
safe regardless of their identities is clearly not applicable for a cohort of concern, as by definition the
cohort could pose a risk even at concentrations below the AET. Since the AET is both an identification
and quantification threshold, the cohorts of concern present an analytical dilemma in the sense that it
is impossible to know whether a compound whose concentration is less than the AET is from a cohort of
concern unless the compound is identified at the extent that its molecular structure can be established
in sufficient detail to allow for a toxicological risk assessment. Although there are several options for
reconciling the AET with potential cohorts of concern, some are not practical. For example, rejecting
the AET concept based on the possibility that there might be an extractable that is a cohort of concern
is likely an excessively conservative response to a relatively low probability circumstance. Rather, the
decision is whether to accept the low risk of a cohort of concern and apply the AET to all the analytical
responses or to perform testing whose purpose is to establish whether one or more substances from a
cohort of concern could be present. To facilitate the decision-making process, the following approach is
recommended.
—	 When there is experimental evidence or a compositional reason to suspect that a cohort of concern
could be present, then either the general absence of cohorts of concern should be established by
information gathering and proper documentation, or the extracts should be screened for targeted
potential substances from cohorts of concern. In the absence of cohorts of concern, the AET can
be applied to all analytical responses. If cohorts of concern are present, then the AET can only be
applied to those analytical responses that are not attributable to cohorts of concern. Analytical
responses attributable to a cohort substance should be safety assessed based on the concentration
of the cohort substance and its toxicological safety data.
—	 When there is no experimental evidence or a compositional reason that suggests that a cohort
substance could be present, it can be concluded that it is unlikely that a cohort of concern is present
and the AET can be applied to all analytical responses.

ISO 10993-18:2020(E)
Annex F
(informative)

Qualification of analytical methods used for extractables/
leachables
An analytical method is qualified to establish that it is suited for its intended purpose. In extractables/
leachables studies, analytical methods serve one of two purposes; screening samples for unspecified
analytes and testing samples for specified (targeted) analytes. As these purposes are quite different, it
is reasonable to suspect that their qualification would differ.
The qualification of an analytical method is documented in a qualification protocol, which establishes the:
—	 relevant qualification parameters;
—	 experimental means by which the qualification parameters will be assessed;
—	 performance expectations for each parameter.
Qualification parameters that are specifically relevant to screening methods include:
—	 sensitivity, as it is expected that the method’s LOQ be less than or equal to the reporting threshold
(note that this expectation is discussed in greater detail in Annex E);
NOTE 1
In cases of very low reporting thresholds, it might not be possible to achieve an LOQ which is
less than or equal to the reporting threshold. In such cases, the lowest reasonably attainable LOQ should be
used, and all analytes above this LOQ should be reported. If the LOQ is higher than the AET, this should be
explained and justified.
—	 specificity, which is ability to assess unequivocally the analyte in the presence of other constituents
that can be expected in the sample;
—	 accuracy, taken as the ability to produce a response that is comparable to the true value (e.g. a
measured concentration in a spiked extract that is comparable to the spiked amount). Accuracy
for screening tests is typically accomplished using surrogate substances that are representative of
extractables;
—	 precision, taken as the variation in replicate analyses of either the same extract or a standard
solution containing extractables or leachables;
—	 dynamic range, taken as the concentration range over which the response and the analyte
concentration producing that response are relatable by a simple mathematical function. Dynamic
range can be established by analysis of surrogate or standard solutions at various concentrations.
NOTE 2
The objectives of this parameter can be achieved within establishment of the LOQ along with
system suitability results.
NOTE 3
Dilution might be needed if analytes of interest are clearly out of range.
Qualification parameters that are specifically relevant to targeting methods include:
—	 sensitivity, relevant in the circumstance that the method’s range includes, or is near to, the LOQ;
—	 specificity, as described for screening methods;
—	 accuracy, as described for screening methods; however, as opposed to screening tests, accuracy in
targeting is accomplished with the actual substances being targeted;

ISO 10993-18:2020(E)
NOTE 4
Spiking samples can help to determine the recovery.
—	 precision, as described for screening methods;
—	 dynamic range, taken as the concentration range over which the response and the analyte
concentration producing that response are relatable by a simple mathematical function. Dynamic
range can be established by analysis of standard solutions at various concentrations;
—	 goodness of fit, taken as the degree to which a simple mathematical function can express the
relationship between an analyte’s concentration in a standard and the method response obtained
when the standard is analysed. Although the desired mathematical function is generally a linear
function, simple, non-linear functions can be used if they are able to meet the acceptance criteria for
goodness of fit.
Qualifying that a method is rugged is relevant for both screening and targeting methods.
Additional performance parameters can be included in a qualification at the discretion of the method’s
user and with appropriate justification. These additional parameters could include: robustness,
efficiency (for a chromatographic separation this might include resolution), matrix effects, sample and
standard stability.
Given their different purpose and function, the processes of qualifying a screening or targeting
method will be different, even if the qualifying criteria are generally the same. For example, while both
screening and targeted methods are qualified for accuracy, the nature of the qualification activity is
different. While accuracy is established in a targeting method specifically for the analyte(s) of interest,
in a screening method accuracy is established more generally by considering a group of surrogate
analytes. Additionally, as screening methods provide concentration estimates, the acceptance criterion
for accuracy is less rigorous than the acceptance criterion for accuracy in targeted analysis, where the
calculated concentration is expected to be highly quantitative.
The same concept is applicable to precision, as it is generally accepted that the precision expectations
for a targeting method are more rigorous than are the precision expectations for a screening method.
Specificity is important in a screening method as the identification of individual extractables is
facilitated if the chromatographic peak associated with an extractable is produced by only that
extractable. In a targeting method, specificity for the targeted compound, meaning that the target
compound’s chromatographic peak is pure, is necessary to provide the required degree of accuracy
and precision. Because a targeted substance is established in advance of implementing the method,
specificity can be established up-front. However, since it is not possible to establish up-front what
analytes might be discovered in screening, specificity in screening methods is typically established
at time of use. Thus, specificity could be measured and judged quite differently in screening versus
targeting.
A method is considered to be qualified (that is, suited for its intended use) when
—	 it has been established that the method is able to routinely meet the performance expectations
contained in the qualification protocol, and
—	 appropriate system suitability has been established.
In addition to having documented performance capabilities, qualified analytical methods should have
additional controls that may include, but are not limited to:
—	 documentation of the method in the form of a standard operating procedure (SOP) which is
controlled in a document change system;
—	 an approved and specified Scope, captured in the method’s SOP;
—	 a detailed scientific description and justification of the method, establishing its suitability for the
intended use;

ISO 10993-18:2020(E)
—	 a requirement that the qualified method is implemented by an appropriately qualified and
trained staff;
—	 a requirement that the qualified method is implemented on calibrated/qualified instrumentation.
Considering system suitability specifically, establishing system suitability is a time of use assessment
that addresses three performance aspects of the method:
a)	 the method has been set up and implemented properly;
b)	 the method as set up is capable of performing at the same level it performed at during its
qualification;
c)
that the method has performed acceptably throughout its use.
System suitability assessment should focus on that minimum number of performance characteristics
which individually and in aggregate demonstrate that these three performance criteria were achieved.
The system suitability parameters to be assessed and their associated acceptance criteria should be
rigorous enough to ensure that the method produces data of acceptable quality but not so rigorous
that potentially acceptable analytical runs are rejected on a frequent basis. Properly collected and
statistically evaluated system suitability data can provide diagnostic evidence of imminent method
failure.
Reference [23] can provide helpful information when devising and implementing a method qualification
process. The reporting of method qualification information is addressed, to a certain extent, in Annex G.

ISO 10993-18:2020(E)
Annex G
(informative)

Reporting details for analytical methods and chemical data
G.1	 General
Clause 7 provided general guidelines in terms of the type of chemical and compositional information
that should be reported, facilitating the information’s use in a toxicological risk assessment. Users
should recognize that additional details can be necessary for regulatory review of the analytical
methods and chemical data. Such information includes:
G.2	 Reporting of analytical data to facilitate toxicological risk assessment
—	 Accounting of qualitative data generated (e.g. extractable’s identities).
—	 Accounting of quantitative data generated (e.g. extractable’s concentrations, including a discussion
of the quantification approach and providing the classification of the quantitative data as estimated
quantitative analysis, semi-quantitative analysis or quantitative analysis).
—	 A discussion and justification of the reporting threshold and its relevance to toxicological risk
assessment (e.g. safety thresholds).
—	 List of chemical compounds above the reporting threshold. Such a list can be provided in a tabular
format and the table should contain the chemical compounds including their mass, proposed
structure, chemical formula, IUPAC chemical name, common chemical name(s) and abbreviation(s),
CAS registry number, their identification status (e.g. confirmed, confident, tentative, speculative) and
their measured levels in the relevant samples. Additional information, such as chemical structure,
may be provided in the document. When multiple candidate identifications are found (e.g. a class of
compounds such as is often reported in tentative identifications), all should be reported.
—	 Information about the device’s clinical use which, when combined with the chemical data, allows for
the calculation of the worst-case amount of the chemical in appropriate units (e.g. µg/medical device)
that can be readily used in toxicological risk assessment (establishing human daily exposure).
—	 Appropriate figures, diagrams, etc. that illustrate the analytical data and/or facilitates data review
and/or interpretation (e.g. labelled chromatograms, migration curves).
—	 Approach and rationale addressing cohorts of concern substances (see E.5).
Note that the reporting of analytical data should facilitate the calculation of estimated clinical exposure
to the reported chemicals, as this is an essential aspect of the toxicological risk assessment. It is not
necessary that the analytical reports themselves contain these estimated exposures.
While the information outlined above is sufficient to enable toxicological risk assessment, it typically
is not sufficient to fully specify and justify the experimental and analytical approaches that were
used to perform a specific study to produce specific data and information. This critical information is
used to establish the validity of the experimental design, the applicability of the analytical approach
and the suitability of the specific analytical methods employed for their intended purpose, during,
for example, regulatory review. Thus, a report should include some of the following information to
provide the proper context with respect to the experimental design, the experimental approach and the
experimental methods.
﻿

ISO 10993-18:2020(E)
G.3	 Details of test article preparation (extraction)
—	 Appropriate and complete description of the test article, including relevant processing details (e.g.
sterilization, rinsing), and parts removed, if applicable;
—	 Extraction method with justification (e.g. refluxing, sealed vessel);
—	 List of extraction vehicles with justification;
—	 Extraction vehicle/ sample ratio (e.g. extracted surface area to extraction solution volume ratio);
—	 Extraction time and temperature;
—	 Number of extraction cycles (e.g. single vs. exhaustive);
—	 Methods for determining when exhaustive extraction endpoints are reached (as appropriate);
—	 Description of changes to the vehicle or test article (e.g. medical device) post-extraction, to include
physical state, appearance, colour, clarity, or presence of particles;
—	 If particles are present in the extract, a description of how they were addressed, including, if
performed, the means by which they were separated from the extract prior to analysis and the
means by which they were chemically characterized.
G.4	 Extract preparation for analysis
—	 Description of any dilution, concentration and other significant processing steps (e.g. vehicle
exchange).
—	 Justification for all significant processing steps.
—	 Description of any sample filtering/particle separation that was performed.
—	 Description of the storage conditions and duration of extracts, if stored prior to analysis.
G.5	 Description of the analytical methods for testing prepared extracts (include
all that apply)
—	 Justification for choice.
—	 Relevant operating conditions (e.g. chromatographic mobile phase, methods, flow rates, gradient
run time, column temperature).
—	 Analytical column; Dimensions and stationary phase used.
—	 Analytical instrumentation manufacturer, model, principal components.
—	 For methods using mass spectrometric detection:
—	 ionization technique (APCI, ESI),
—	 polarity mode (positive, negative),
—	 mass range (or specific masses analysed for ICP-MS data),
—	 nominal mass resolution.
—	 For methods using UV detection, detection wavelength.
—	 For other detection methods, key operational parameters.

t17        Reporting of the chemical characterization datat17        Tolerable contact level, tolerable intake and threshold of toxicological concern
2The purpose of a chemical assessment report is to provide information that enables the review of
3chemical characterization data and supports the toxicological risk assessment of this information.
4Such reports shall clearly state the purpose and objectives of the chemical assessment that has been
5performed and shall include description and justification for the following:
6a)       test article (material or medical device) description and details of sample preparation;
7b)       analytical methods and extraction conditions (e.g. choice of extraction vehicles, extraction duration
8and cycles, extraction temperature, extraction/sample ratio, agitation method and speed during
9extraction);
10c)
11documentation of system suitability testing and its outcome;
12d)       value for, and justification of, the reporting threshold (e.g. AET);
13e)       qualitative data generated (e.g. extractables' identities, including a description of the identification
14procedure);
15f)
16quantitative data generated (e.g. extractables’ concentrations, including a description of the
17quantification procedures and providing the classification of the quantitative data as estimated
18quantitative analysis, semi-quantitative analysis or quantitative analysis);
19g)       information necessary to estimate clinical exposure to chemicals (e.g. analyte amounts in µg/
20device).
21As necessary and appropriate, identified substances in the test solutions could be grouped into
22compound classes, based on structural or functional group similarities, to assist in any toxicological
23risk assessment.
24Chemical or compositional information or data that is obtained without the device’s sponsor having to
25perform testing (e.g. data supplied by a material’s vendor, data available from the chemical literature)
26can be included in reports, as relevant and appropriate. Reporting requirements for data obtained from
27such additional sources include the same items noted above for sponsor-generated test data but in
28addition would include a discussion of its relevance to the toxicological risk assessment.
29In addition to containing the necessary study design-related details and the relevant and appropriate
30chemical assessment data, thereby facilitating study review and toxicological risk assessment, a report
31should contain sufficient information to establish the appropriateness of the analytical processes
32employed. Such information would be relevant to establishing that the analytical procedures were
33suitable for their intended use and implemented appropriately at their time of use.
34Types of information that can be included in a report to facilitate the toxicological risk assessment and
35the review of the analytical data and procedures are listed in Annex G.

47General principles of chemical characterization
48A.1      The chemical characterization process
49Chemical characterization is the process of obtaining chemical information about a medical device,
50relevant to its biological evaluation and any toxicological risk assessment. Chemical characterization of
51a medical device, its components, or its materials of construction involves multiple processes, including
52information gathering and generation, to:
53—        establish the device’s material composition and configuration;
54—        identify and quantify extractables and/or leachables associated with the device.
55Chemically characterizing a medical device and/or its components and materials of construction is a
56necessary aspect in assessing the biological safety of that medical device.
57A.2      The uses of chemical characterization
58Chemical characterization can facilitate the biological safety assessment process in one of three ways
59by providing
60—        the chemical information that enables a comparison between the medical device in question and
61clinically established medical devices (establish equivalence),
62—        the chemical basis for comparing the medical device in question to a relevant material standard
63(confirm conformance), and
64—        the chemical information that serves as the basis for a toxicological risk assessment (enable
65assessment).
66In certain circumstances, the toxicological implications associated with use of a medical device can be
67assessed by comparing the device in question to a clinically established device. In such circumstances,
68chemical characterization is important in establishing chemical equivalence between, for example,
69—        a proposed item (materials, component or device) and a clinically established item (see Annex C),
70—        a finished and marketable medical device and a prototype device, and
71—        a material, component, or medical device after a process, material, application or manufacturing
72change.
73Standards that include requirements for material composition exist for some medical device materials
74(e.g. the ISO  5832 series). It is possible that a material complying with such a standard would not
75require further chemical characterization to support toxicological or biological evaluation. However,
76the conversion of the material into the final form of the medical device can introduce contaminants or
77process residues. These can leach from the medical device and be of toxicological concern. Evaluation of
78the finished medical device should consider and address such leachables. In addition, physical, chemical,
79morphological, and topographical characteristics of a component manufactured with the material may
80need to be assessed to determine the overall safety.
81Lastly, and in other circumstances, most notably at its inception and in the absence of a relevant
82clinically established medical device, the toxicological implications associated with the use of a device,
83including its components or materials of construction, can be assessed using a chemical characterization
84﻿

92approach. Such an approach can include data gathering, data generation (e.g. extractables or leachables
93profiles), and data interpretation.
94An overview of the chemical characterization procedure outlined in this document and its relationship
95to risk assessment is given in Clause 5. The procedure is based on the following considerations.
96a)       The first step in chemical characterization is establishing contact according to ISO 10993-1.
97b)       The extent of chemical characterization (e.g. whether information gathering can be sufficient;
98design of extraction studies, if performed) should reflect:
991)       the nature and duration of the clinical exposure;
1002)       the physical form of the materials used (e.g. liquids, gels, pastes, solids, or biologically sourced
101material);
1023)       the history of use of the materials.
103Further, it should be sufficient to produce the data necessary to establish the biological safety of
104the medical device.
105c)
106Establishing the configuration of a medical device, by delineating its materials of construction, is the
107necessary first step in establishing the device’s biocompatibility as (a) use of appropriate materials
108of construction increases the likelihood a device will be biocompatible and (b) knowledge of the
109materials of construction could provide the starting point for establishing chemical equivalence to
110a clinically established device.
111For some medical devices, configuration and material composition information could be readily
112available to the device manufacturer as part of the device specification, or it could be obtained
113through inquiry. In other circumstances, such information can be obtained by appropriate testing
114of the device. In any case, processing aids and additives (see Table 3, footnotes b and d) should be
115included as part of this compositional information.
116d)       Establishing the composition of a medical device’s materials of construction is a necessary step
117in establishing a device’s biocompatibility, as (a) the composition of the individual materials of
118construction can serve as the basis for establishing chemical equivalence to a clinically established
119device, and (b) the chemical entities contained in a material of construction can be sources of
120extractables and leachables.
1211)       Compositional data include qualitative data, which describe the composition of a material and
122establish which chemicals are present in the material, and quantitative data which establish
123the concentrations of the material’s chemical constituents. Quantitative information can
124be necessary to assess biological safety, as the identity and amounts of the constituents of a
125medical device’s materials of construction enables the investigation of the intrinsic toxicity of
126each constituent. The data obtained are intended for use by the medical device manufacturer
127to support the biological evaluation of the medical device.
1282)       For some materials, compositional information could be readily available as part of the material
129specification. As materials such as polymers can have complex formulations, compositional
130details should be requested from the supplier of the material. Furthermore, some relevant
131information can be available in the published chemical literature (e.g. typical variability
132in composition or guidance on possible analytes of interest). In the absence of such details,
133appropriate analytical techniques can be applied to a material to obtain compositional data.
134e)       Determining the medical device’s potential to release chemical substances under clinical
135use conditions can provide the basis for understanding and assessing the device’s potential
136safety impact. Although any of the substances in a material or additives used in the process of
137manufacturing a medical device could be leached from the device and thereby become bio-available,
138it could potentially be necessary to obtain information demonstrating the extent to which the
139substances will be leached under the clinical use conditions of the finished product to estimate
140the risk arising from them. This can be estimated by conducting extraction studies of the medical

149device. Appropriate extraction conditions should be established, justified and then used to ensure
150that any substance which is likely to be released during finished product use will be released into
151the extraction media (see also Annex D). Extractions can be used to determine the total amount of
152extractable materials that is present in the medical device/material (exhaustive extraction) or the
153total available amount of extractable material (exaggerated or simulated use extraction) in order
154to complete the toxicological risk assessment. Exhaustive extractions are generally necessary
155to produce sufficient data for medical devices with prolonged or long-term contact; exaggerated
156extractions should only be used for long term contact devices if appropriately justified.
157Regardless of the means by which the extract is obtained, the extract is quantitatively analysed to
158generate the data for use in the toxicological risk assessment of the medical device (see ISO 10993-17).
159Depending on the nature and sources of the chemical information to be assembled, the successful
160completion of the chemical characterization outlined in this document can require expertise in material
161science or analytical chemistry to provide the necessary qualitative and quantitative data that a risk
162assessor can use to assess medical device safety. Toxicology expertise is valuable in understanding the
163types of compounds that might be of toxicological concern so that the materials and chemistry experts
164can design appropriate experiments.
165The chemical characterization outlined in this document is performed as part of the initial
166biocompatibility assessment of the medical device. It is noted that the biological safety of the medical
167device is inferred over the medical device’s time in market only so long as the device’s materials of
168construction and manufacturing process remain unchanged. It is important that controls be introduced
169to prevent a material supplier from changing the composition of a material supplied under a specific
170commercial trade name or supply agreement without prior notification to the medical device
171manufacturer. The manufacturer should assess and document the consequences of any notified changes
172on the biological safety of the product.
173A.3      The analytical evaluation threshold
174An important aspect of extractables/leachables analysis is the testing of a liquid sample (e.g. extract,
175digest) to detect, identify, and quantify solubilized (extracted or leached) substances. For the purposes
176of toxicological assessment, the analytical test methods will be capable of detecting, identifying, and
177quantifying solubilized substances in the extract at the levels which could potentially have an effect
178on the health of potentially affected individuals in contact with a medical device. However, in certain
179circumstances some essential chemical characterization activities, such as identification, cannot be
180performed. In the absence of reliable identification or sufficient toxicological information for identified
181compounds, the probable risk can often be inferred via the application of toxicological threshold
182concepts. Accordingly, substances lower than such a threshold do not require further chemical
183characterization, including identification and quantification. It is noted that these thresholds make
184exceptions for special case compounds of known high toxicity.
185If a threshold is expressed in terms of dose, then it is not directly applicable to analytical
186characterization of a liquid test sample. However, these thresholds can be converted to a concentration
187via the appropriate mathematical conversion, which takes into account the clinical use of the medical
188device and the experimental conditions used to derive the liquid sample. Such a concentration-based
189threshold, termed the AET, becomes that threshold above which an analytical chemist should produce
190that information (concentration and identity) which is necessary for toxicological risk assessment (e.g.
191application of ISO 10993-17). A substance that is present in a liquid sample at a concentration below the
192AET is established as having an acceptable toxicological risk without further assessment, meaning that
193the substance does not have to be accurately quantified or identified.
194The AET is not applicable to analytical targeting methods in which the specified analytes are compounds
195with sufficient toxicological safety data to address using ISO 10993-17.
196The calculation and application of the AET is discussed in greater detail in Annex E.

204ISO 10993-18:2020(E)
205A.4      The role of chemical characterization in biological analysis
206The primary objective of ISO 10993 is the protection of humans from potential biological risks arising
207from the use of medical devices. This objective is achieved via the biological evaluation of medical
208devices, which includes the means (testing procedures) for producing the biological data and the means
209of interpreting the biological data in the context of a risk assessment.
210Generally, biocompatibility information can be obtained from two types of assessments: (1) chemical
211characterization coupled with relevant toxicology data, and (2) biological testing. Generally, risk
212assessment should include the proper mix of chemical and biological data, which can vary depending
213upon the circumstances. If information from both types of assessments address the same biological
214endpoint in a comparable manner, information from either type of assessment could be used to address
215that endpoint. However, in vitro tests should be favoured as far as possible (see ISO 10993-2). In the
216event conflicting data is obtained, the biological test (given it has acceptable sensitivity) should be
217given greater weight due to its being directly applicable to biological systems.
218The general category of biological evaluation can be further subdivided into two sub-categories: those
219types of testing that evaluate a systemic effect (i.e. one that depends on systemic distribution of extracts
220or leachates), and those that evaluate local effects (i.e. those that occur in the vicinity of the medical
221device). Tests that evaluate systemic effects, or endpoints (e.g. systemic toxicity) are more likely to be
222suitably addressed by chemical characterization than are those tests for local effects (e.g. irritation and
223implantation effects). Endpoints that have both local and systemic effects (e.g. sensitization) may be
224addressed through chemical characterization, if sufficient toxicology data exist.
225The use of chemical characterization in place of biological testing should be documented and justified.

237Information sources for chemical characterization
238B.1      General
239Knowledge of a medical device’s material composition is an essential input into a device’s biological
240evaluation and toxicological risk assessment (see ISO  10993-1 and ISO  10993-17). As described in
241ISO 10993-1:2018, 6.1, the type and amount of characterization data should be consistent with all of
242the parameters considered relevant to the risk assessment of the medical device and should consider
243the clinical application. Gathering of chemical characterization data could require the use of multiple
244sources of information as described in B.2 to B.4 and could include a review of the available published
245chemical literature.
246B.2      Information from the material supplier
247The following information, where available, is useful to specify the material used (e.g. raw and basic
248starting materials, processing aids), and the compositional information is particularly useful to aid
249quantitative risk assessment:
250a)       name of material manufacturer or supplier;
251b)       generic material trade name;
252EXAMPLE
253Silastic®, Dacron®, Tetoron®, Pellethane®, Nylon, Teflon®1).
254c)
255chemical identifier (e.g. CAS number) or systematic name (IUPAC/USAN) (see B.5);
256d)       product code and number;
257EXAMPLE
258Pellethane 2393-80AE, methylvinylpolysiloxane 0215.
259e)       material manufacturer's specification, including, for example, purity, impurity identities and levels,
260quality, molecular weight, molecular weight distribution, thermal properties, tensile strength,
261Rockwell hardness, bending modulus, conduction of electricity, and others in addition to the
262general parameters described in 5.2;
263f)
264details of material composition and formulation (see 5.2) such as Chemical Abstracts Service (CAS)
265numbers (see B.5.2), mass fraction in percent (%) of each chemical in the formulation, function of
266each chemical constituent, and structure and formula of each chemical;
267NOTE
268For medical grade components often used in medical devices, a detailed description can be
269found in material standards [e.g. ASTM F136-13 Standard Specification for Wrought Titanium-6Aluminum-
2704Vanadium ELI (Extra Low Interstitial) Alloy for Surgical Implant Applications], and sometimes in
271pharmacopoeias.
272g)       certificates of compliance with regional compendia and relevant global regulations (e.g. REACH,
273indirect food additives).
2741)        Silastic®, Dacron®, Tetoron®, Pellethane®, Nylon, Teflon® are examples of suitable products available
275commercially. This information is given for the convenience of users of this document and does not constitute an
276endorsement by ISO of these products.

285B.3      Chemical analyses
286B.3.1    General
287Further to Clause 6, several modes of chemical analyses are described in B.3.2 to B.3.5.
288B.3.2 Non-specific chemical analysis relevant to exposure assessment
289Non-specific chemical analyses have been included in some international standards and national
290guidelines or standards intended to ensure safety. These methods are generally usable for an imprecise,
291first pass estimation of the chemical hazards of medical devices, though their direct relationship to
292safety is limited. Some examples are given below:
293EXAMPLE 1
294OECD Guidelines; Test No. 120[17].
295This test protocol[17] describes the procedure for determining the solution/extraction behaviour of
296polymers in water at 20 °C at pH 2 and pH 9 and at 37 °C at pH 7. Total organic carbon content (TOC)
297analysis is recommended for determining total polymeric species in aqueous phase. Other more specific
298methods are also described.
299EXAMPLE 2
300JP XVII[21], USP 41[22] or Ph. Eur. Ed. 9[20].
301The JP and Ph. Eur methods (see References [21] and [20]) include test methods and specifications for
302residue on ignition, heavy metals, extractable substances such as potassium permanganate-reducing
303substances and residue of evaporation. The USP methods (Reference [22]) include test methods and
304specifications for acidity/alkalinity, UV absorbance, total organic carbon  (TOC), extractable metals,
305polymer additives and biocompatibility.
306B.3.3    Qualitative analysis
307If material composition and/or formulation is required but the available qualitative information is
308judged to be incomplete or not available, further chemical testing can be necessary. Depending on the
309information needs, qualitative or quantitative information might be required.
310Many of the analytical methods employed for chemical characterization are capable of both qualitative
311and quantitative analyses. However, the purpose of the qualitative analysis is to provide a list of
312identified chemical constituents in a sample. Conversely, the aim of quantitative analysis is to establish
313the level or amount of each individual chemical constituent in a sample, whether the constituent
314is identified or not. Since a toxicological risk assessment is typically based on both identity (which
315establishes the constituent’s toxic potential) and concentration (which establishes exposure), both
316qualitative and quantitative analyses are important and relevant.
317NOTE
318Semi-quantitative methods can be sufficient for an initial risk assessment, and quantitative methods
319might be needed when a specific risk has been identified (i.e. an inadequate margin of safety found after semi-
320quantitative analysis).
321B.3.4 Quantitative analysis of specific toxic chemicals for exposure assessment
322If qualitative analyses identify chemicals of toxicological concern, then quantitative and specific
323analysis should be performed. The specificity, level of sensitivity and limit of quantification of the
324analytical method should be sufficient for the required level of risk assessment.
325B.3.5    Qualitative and quantitative analytical methods
326NMR, attenuated total reflectance/Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (ATR/FT-IR) and pyrolysis
327gas chromatography/mass spectrometry are useful methods for compositional and formulation
328analyses. Medical device or material extracts can be analysed by chromatographic methods combined
329with appropriate detection techniques (e.g. GC and LC each combined with MS) to identify and
330quantify, as appropriate, extracted substances. Inductively coupled plasma  (ICP) analysis is useful
331for establishing the levels of elements present in extracts or digests of medical devices or materials,

343B.4 National and international material and/or product standards
344Most material and/or product standards specify a quality of material in the standard in relation to the
345purpose of use. When the material used in the medical device meets such a standard and when the
346category and duration of contact of the device are comparable to those in the standard, giving the title
347and number of the standard can be sufficient for characterization of the material. Applicability of these
348standards for chemical characterization depends on the following factors.
349—        Does the standard specify the medical device and its contact and duration?
350—        Does the standard specify the material (e.g. specific material, category of material)? If so, to
351what extent?
352—        Does the standard set any limits on the level of certain chemicals? Are such limits comprehensive,
353specific, general, or total?
354—        Does the medical device or material standardized have a history of safe clinical use?
355The extent to which these factors are addressed in the standard determines the extent to which their
356use can fulfil chemical characterization needs.
357NOTE
358Use of material standards might not be sufficient to address the effects that manufacturing and
359processing can have on materials when incorporated into the final device. For example, the manufacturing
360process for medical devices manufactured out of metallic materials described in national and international
361material or product standards can have a negative influence upon the overall biocompatibility, as residues of
362cutting oils used during the CNC cutting process can be insufficiently removed.
363B.5      Reporting chemical descriptions of materials
364B.5.1    Generic name of material
365The generic name should be supplied with references to the specific chemical name.
366NOTE
367Generic names can be misunderstood. For instance, “polyester” refers to a class of polymers comprised
368of ester linkages, but is commonly used to refer specifically to poly(ethylene terephthalate).
369B.5.2    Other nomenclatures and chemical descriptions of materials
370B.5.2.1  General
371There are several nomenclature systems that specify the materials more exactly.
372B.5.2.2  IUPAC nomenclature and structure formulae of polymeric chemicals
373The International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry  (IUPAC) Macromolecular Nomenclature
374Commission has published rules for naming polymers[37]. Naming and describing polymers according
375to the rules present some exact features of polymeric chemicals as defined. It does not give any
376information however about the commercially available polymers that often contain some additives.
377B.5.2.3 CAS Registry number, USAN, REACH and other registry name and/or number
378Chemical Abstract Service (CAS) and United States Adopted Names (USAN) give a specific number and
379name respectively to newly developed polymeric chemicals such as contact lens materials. When the
380material used has its given CAS No. and/or USAN name, it is easy to discriminate it from similar but not

394B.6      Reporting general information concerning chemical nature of materials
395Several parameters are generally usable to specify the chemical nature of the material used. These
396parameters differ by category of materials. For synthetic polymers, examples of such parameters
397are molecular mass and its distribution, glass transition temperature, melting point, specific gravity,
398solubility and swelling nature.
399NOTE
400The OECD Guidelines, Section 1, Test No. 118:1996 can be useful for synthetic polymers[16].
401B.7 Material master file
402When it can be secured, a master file may be used in the review of a pending application for marketing
403authorization of a specific medical device. It often contains detailed information about a specific
404material formulation, or its processing, which is used in a medical device. It is a reference source that
405allows a third party to submit information to a regulatory agency. A master file is useful for supporting
406equivalence of a material or suitability of a material for a specific category of use. Its contents are
407considered to be trade secret or commercially confidential information.

419Principles for establishing biological equivalence
420C.1      General
421As noted in 5.3, it can be appropriate to compare a new or modified medical device (or material) with
422an existing clinically established medical device (material). When the term medical device is used in
423this annex, it is understood that the same concepts are applicable to materials as well. The purpose of
424such a comparison would be to establish whether the new or modified medical device is biologically
425equivalent to the existing medical device since if biological equivalence can be established then the
426existing medical device’s biocompatibility can be extended to the new or modified medical device.
427C.2      Principles of biological equivalence
428The concept of biological equivalence consists of the following elements (Figure C.1):
429—        Chemical equivalence: situation where the chemical characteristics of two materials or medical
430devices are sufficiently similar, such that the composition and processing do not result in additional
431or different toxicological concerns.
432—        Physical equivalence: situation where the physical characteristics of two materials or medical devices
433are sufficiently similar, such that the configuration, morphology, topography (per ISO/TS 10993-19)
434and tribology do not result in additional or different biocompatibility concerns.
435—        Material equivalence: situation where two materials or medical devices demonstrate chemical and
436physical equivalence.
437—        Contact equivalence: situation where the intended clinical use of two materials or medical devices
438is sufficiently similar that the endpoints of biological evaluation identified in ISO 10993-1:2018, A.1
439are identical.
440—        Biological equivalence: situation where two materials or medical devices demonstrate material and
441contact equivalence.
442Figure C.1 — Biological equivalence relationship map

451C.3      Process for determining biological equivalence
452Figure C.2 describes the process for determining biological equivalence between two medical devices.
453Figure C.2 — Biological equivalence process map
454If biological equivalence is established, this satisfactorily completes the biological risk assessment of a
455new or modified medical device.
456If biological equivalence cannot be established, the biocompatibility of a new or modified medical device
457can only be established based on the medical device’s own contact, chemical, physical, toxicological and
458biological characteristics.
459C.4      Examples of chemical equivalence
460The following list of examples is provided to assist with establishing chemical equivalence (according
461to 5.3), where the requirements of chemical equivalence are met.
462a)       The composition or extractables profile of the proposed material is equivalent (i.e. same chemicals
463at the same or lower level and no new chemicals) to that of a clinically established material, and

472there are no significant differences in physical, chemical, morphological and topographical
473characteristics which could impact the biological safety of the medical device.
474NOTE
475If there are slight increases in any chemicals, it can be reasonable to justify chemical equivalence
476within the statistical variability of the semi-quantitative methods being used. Use of calibration standards
477across a range of chemistries and concentrations can be helpful to this approach.
478b)       A material that is already clinically established in a more invasive exposure is proposed to be used
479in a comparable but less invasive application, where less invasive is understood in the context of
480ISO 10993-1 as having a shorter duration of contact or a contact category calling for fewer endpoints
481to be addressed.
482c)
483A chemical constituent or residue in a clinically established material is replaced in the proposed
484material with a chemical constituent or residue whose toxicological safety profile is no worse than
485that of the constituent or residue that it is replacing, assuming similar exposure.
486d)       The only difference between a proposed material and a clinically established material is that the
487proposed material has eliminated or reduced the level of an additive/contaminant/residue present
488in the clinically established material.
489e)       The only difference between a proposed material and a clinically established material is that the
490proposed material is produced using processing conditions that either maintain or reduce the
491number and/or levels of extractables in the clinically established material.
492f)
493A material in a clinically established medical device is moved to a location in a proposed medical
494device where contact between a potentially affected individual and the material is lessened.
495g)       Both the proposed material and the clinically established material meet relevant and rigorous
496compositional specifications.

508Principles of sample extraction
509D.1      General
510Information generation in the chemical characterization of a medical device and/or its materials of
511construction is typically a two-step process in which the medical device or material is extracted and
512the extract is subsequently chemically analysed to establish the extracted substances. The goal of the
513extraction is to produce an extractables profile that equals or exceeds the leachables generated in clinical
514use but does not cause deleterious effects to the materials (such as degradation) or the extractables
515profile (such as chemical alteration of the extractables). Doing so may provide an extractables profile
516that is at least as extensive as the medical device’s leachables profile, meaning that the extractables
517profile minimally accounts for the leachables and their levels. Under certain circumstances (e.g.
518exhaustive extractions), the extractables profile can greatly exaggerate the actual chemical release,
519meaning that the extractables represent all possible leachables at their highest possible concentration.
520However, it should be noted that all leachables might not necessarily be present in the extractables
521profile. Extractables studies which differ significantly from simulated use conditions in terms of solvent
522properties and extraction method might not fully represent every leachable compound which would be
523observed under simulated use conditions. This should be taken into account in design of extractables
524studies and determination of when chemical characterization is complete (according to Figure 1).
525As chemical characterization is a general term that describes several individual activities with varying
526objectives (e.g. compositional analysis, extractables profiling), it is clear that there are numerous
527means of performing an extraction, where the means of performing an extraction is closely linked to
528the objective of the characterization. Thus, an extraction to support establishment of the composition
529of a medical device is necessarily and appropriately performed differently from an extraction done to
530support establishment of the medical device’s extractables profile under the device’s typical clinical use
531conditions.
532In general, there can be four objectives of extractions for a chemical characterization:
533—        to establish the compositional aspects of the configuration of a medical device or the composition of
534a material of construction (digestion, dissolution or exhaustive extraction);
535—        to establish the worst-case extractables profile of a medical device or material as either the total
536pool of extractables in the medical device (exhaustive extraction) or the maximum amount that can
537be extracted under defined experimental conditions that exaggerate a device’s clinical conditions of
538use (exaggerated or accelerated extraction);
539—        to establish the extractables profile of a medical device or material under its clinical conditions of
540use (simulated extraction);
541—        to correlate chemical data to the results of biological testing performed as described elsewhere in
542ISO 10993.
543Each of these cases will be considered in greater detail in subsequent clauses with respect to
544establishing appropriate extraction conditions that are consistent with the objectives of the case.
545Regardless of the type of extraction performed, extraction is a complex process influenced by aspects
546including time, temperature, surface area-to-volume ratio, extraction vehicle and the partitioning
547behaviour of the substances in the test article relative to the extraction vehicle. In general, the
548extraction conditions should not alter the test article, unless justified, as alteration of the test article
549could change the amount and/or type of extractables released from the test article. Thus, the material’s

558chemical properties might also need to be considered when selecting extraction vehicles, for example,
559to avoid or enhance (e.g. in dissolution studies) solubilisation of the base material.
560As stated in ISO 10993-12:2012, 3.8, extraction conditions are expected to be at least as aggressive
561as the conditions of clinical use. However, for extractables and leachables studies, avoid using
562extraction solvents that can cause significant swelling and/or compromise the integrity of the test
563article. Significant swelling can cause reduction of free extraction solvent, which could impact the
564concentration of extractables and lead to inaccurate analytical calculations. Regarding evaporative loss
565that might occur during extraction, it is not recommended to compensate for solvent loss by adding
566additional solvent after extraction is complete; rather, steps should be taken to reduce evaporative
567loss (e.g. by covering sample containers), or the final extract volume should be measured for later
568calculations on extractables device. Measurement of solvent volumes in order to compensate for solvent
569loss due to swelling should be done cautiously, given that the amount of solvent that swells a test article
570might be unknown and difficult to measure. In either case, the final extract volume should be measured
571and reported for later calculations on extractables per device. Furthermore, destructive swelling can
572induce material/medical device disintegration and result in particulate debris, and extractables and
573leachables that would not otherwise be present; this could potentially interfere with analysis.
574Although choice of extraction vehicles will depend on the specific extraction objectives, it is generally
575appropriate for long-term implants that a minimum of two extraction solvents of differing polarity
576be employed; for example, polar and non-polar vehicles consistent with ISO  10993-12. For medical
577devices with indirect contact, it can be appropriate to use a single extraction solvent that replicates the
578expected contacting fluid. In any case, the choice of extraction vehicle(s) shall be justified.
579NOTE
580For some regulatory regions, such as the U.S., three solvents (e.g. polar, non-polar, and semi-polar) are
581recommended for long term implants, unless justified.
582Examples of possible extraction vehicles are presented in Table  D.1. Inclusion of these solvents in
583Table D.1 serves only as a starting point for solvent vehicles selection and does not constitute a complete
584justification for their use.
585SAFETY PRECAUTIONS — If hazardous solvents are used, occupational health requirements
586should be observed.

680The polarity index developed by Snyder was derived empirically from data on mixtures of solvents
681commonly used in chromatography (GC stationary phases and LC mobile phases)[49]. Other
682categorization schemes have been proposed for categorizing solvent extraction power. For example,
683Hansen[35] has expanded the Hildebrand solubility parameter ‘δ’[36], attempting to account for
684the effects of dispersion forces, dipole moments, and hydrogen bonding. When Hansen solubility
685parameters are available for both material and solvents, they can provide an estimation of the degree of
686interaction between materials and solvents; materials with similar solubility parameters can interact
687with each other, resulting in solvation, miscibility or swelling. Either of these scales can contribute to
688the rationale for selection of vehicles for extraction in chemical characterization. Stults, et al.[52] have
689compiled some information on plastic and elastomer compatibility with several common solvents.

724D.2 Approaches to establishing the compositional aspects of the configuration of
725a medical device or the composition of a material of construction
726The terms composition applied to a material and configuration applied to a medical device address the
727same concept in that they both establish what chemical entities are present in the test article and at
728what amounts they are present. Although certain non-destructive test methods exist for establishing
729composition and configuration, it is typically the case that both require test article solubilisation
730followed by chemical testing of the resulting solution. When solubilisation is used, it can be accomplished
731in several different manners including digestion or dissolution.

740ISO 10993-18:2020(E)
741To establish the elemental composition of a ceramic, metallic or polymeric test articles, digestion using
742an appropriate chemical (e.g. strong acid, base or enzyme) is recommended. In digesting the test article,
743the chemical form of its constituents is largely disrupted and the constituents are typically converted
744to their elemental form. Although the use of digestion is generally not appropriate for assessment
745of extractables, it can facilitate the procurement of otherwise unavailable information on material
746composition and it establishes the absolute and maximum total pool of elemental entities present in a
747test article.
748To establish chemical formulation, dissolution is typically applied to polymeric or natural macromolecule
749test articles via the use of an appropriate organic solvent and is typically performed to establish the
750intact organic and/or inorganic constituents in a test article. Once the test article is dissolved with
751an appropriate vehicle, analysis of the dissolution solution is performed. In many cases, the analysis
752is facilitated after the polymer itself has been re-precipitated with an antivehicle and filtered out.
753Although the use of dissolution is not appropriate for assessment of clinical exposure, unless the medical
754device or material being assessed dissolves in clinical use, it can facilitate the procurement of otherwise
755unavailable information on material composition and it establishes the absolute total and maximum
756pool of constituents in a test article. If this step is undertaken, the possibility of co-precipitation of
757constituents other than the base polymer should be considered.
758Possible solvent/anti-solvent combinations for common polymers are listed in Table D.2 and can be
759found in the literature[28][29][30][31][33][43].

852Other than this general discussion, this annex provides no additional insights on performing dissolutions
853and digestions, as the approaches applied to accomplish dissolution or digestion vary significantly on a
854case by case basis.
855The concept of an exhaustive extraction is discussed in ISO 10993-12:2012, Annex D. An exhaustive
856extraction establishes the maximum amounts of extractables that can be removed (extracted) from the
857medical device or material and thus defines the upper bound on the amount of leachables that could
858potentially be released by the device or material during clinical use/lifetime. In many circumstances,

867an exhaustive extraction will accomplish the same outcome as digestion or dissolution, but without the
868solubilisation of the medical device.
869For long-term implanted medical devices, an exhaustive extraction is recommended. If an exaggerated
870extraction is used, then its use should be justified. It should also be recognized that if total extractables
871from an exhaustive (or justified exaggerated extraction) of a long-term implant medical device exceed
872a permissible daily exposure, the extraction kinetics (e.g. to determine maximum daily release) might
873need to be evaluated (e.g. by repeated analysis of a simulated extraction over time), or a leachables
874study performed, if possible. A toxicologist can be consulted to establish the specific data required to
875support risk assessment when there is a need to understand the kinetics of release.
876As defined in 3.15, exhaustive extraction involves sequential extraction of the test article under
877relevant extraction conditions and with a relevant extraction vehicle and is achieved when the level of
878extracted substance by gravimetric (or other analysis) in a subsequent extraction step is less than 10 %
879of the level of the same extracted substance in the initial extract. Achieving the required 10 % level for
880each individual extractable can be analytically and practically challenging (e.g. when the 10 % level is
881below the method’s LOQ); thus, it might be necessary to establish that the 10 % level of extraction has
882been established by alternate means (e.g. total peak area, TOC, non-volatile residue). Such alternate
883means should be justified. In some cases, the 10 % level cannot be reached in a practical number of
884sequential extractions. In these cases, the analyst should consider an alternate extraction process (e.g.
885use of an extraction vehicle with greater extraction power) so that the 10 % level can be achieved in
886a reasonable number of sequential extractions. It can also be possible to estimate lifetime exposures
887from the sequential amounts extracted, even if the 10 % level is not achieved.
888Additionally, ISO 10993-12:2012, Annex D, describes a set of extraction vehicles [methanol, acetone,
889isopropanol-hexane (50:50) and hexane] that can be used, as appropriate, in preliminary experiments
890whose purpose is to optimize the extraction sequence and discusses the need to use extraction
891conditions and extraction vehicles (including those described above) that do not result in a chemical
892change of either the test article or the extracted chemical entity. Regardless of the specific extraction
893parameters selected, each step of exhaustive extractions should use uniform extraction parameters.
894The means by which the individual extraction steps in a sequential exhaustive extraction are
895accomplished are many and varied. Liquid extraction techniques for polymers span a century in terms
896of development and use and can be divided into two categories “traditional” and “modern”. Traditional
897techniques, including Soxhlet extraction, boiling under reflux, shake flask extraction, and sonication
898are widely used even today and are more or less simple to implement using basic laboratory apparatus.
899As the traditional techniques have been used for an extended period of time, their capabilities and
900performance is well-known and well-documented. Nevertheless, they can have significant practical
901shortcomings including low extraction efficiencies, long extraction times, and the use of large
902quantities of environmentally inopportune extraction vehicles. Such shortcomings are addressed, to
903a certain extent, by the more modern extraction techniques, including microwave-assisted extraction,
904pressurized fluid extraction, and supercritical fluid extraction, which typically employ instrumental
905means to increase the heat and/or the pressure at which extraction occurs or the power of the extraction
906vehicle[26][51]. Nevertheless, the fact that the techniques are more “modern” do not make them superior.
907The use of any technique, “traditional” or “modern”, should carefully and fully consider their technical
908and practical limitations and relevance to the clinical use of medical devices.
909From a practical perspective, sequential extraction is facilitated when the extraction sequence consists
910of the fewest possible number of extraction steps while not degrading the additives and ingredients.
911An exhaustive extraction reveals a test article’s constituents and the levels of these constituents. The
912exhaustive extraction addresses extractables and leachables in the sense of a total leaching, meaning
913that a profile of exhaustive extractables addresses the clinical use situation of “all constituents
914(extractables) are leached in their entirety”. Although such an exhaustive extractables profile can be
915relevant to the clinical use of certain medical devices (e.g., long term implants as noted previously), in
916many cases the clinical leaching of the medical devices is not exhaustive and thus an alternate extraction
917process, such as exaggerated or simulated extraction, produces a more appropriate extractables profile
918for the purpose of toxicological risk assessment. Furthermore, clinical use can, in certain circumstances
919(such as absorbable medical devices) promote the chemical conversion of constituents into related

928substances such as degradation products or side products. If this same conversion does not occur during
929an extraction study (e.g. exhaustive extraction/dissolution), then the exhaustive extraction is not a
930fully accurate representation of a potentially affected individual’s clinical exposure to the chemicals
931present during the medical device use. In such cases, the knowledge of potential intermediate and final
932chemical products, including degradation products, in combination with chemical characterization data
933and implantation data might be needed to evaluate the safety of products. Knowledge of degradation
934process/products should be incorporated into any related toxicology risk assessment, even if the
935degradants are not observed in extracts.
936D.3 Exaggerated extraction to estimate the worst-case extractables profile of
937a medical device or material
938As stated in 3.16, extractables are defined as the substances that are released from a medical device or
939material of construction using extraction vehicles and/or laboratory extraction conditions. However,
940it is clear that the extraction conditions used to establish configuration and composition are generally
941much more extreme than the medical device’s clinical conditions of use, and thus that extractables
942revealed in compositional studies are less likely to appear as leachables from the device under its
943clinical conditions of use. Nevertheless, as discussed in Clause  5, the worst-case assessment of the
944leaching of a medical device considers the situation where all ingredients and additives leach from the
945medical device in their entirety. Should a toxicological risk assessment of this worst-case establish that
946the risk related to the total amount of ingredients and additives be acceptable, then the assessment is
947essentially complete and the medical device is accepted as being suitable for its intended use with no
948further chemical testing.
949However, if the toxicological risk assessment establishes that the worst-case provided by an exhaustive
950extraction could represent a safety issue, then a less extreme, more practical exaggerated estimate of
951the medical device’s leaching characteristics is necessary and appropriate. Such an estimate is obtained
952by using justified exaggerated extraction conditions that somewhat more closely reflect the clinical
953conditions of use. Of course, exaggerated extractions can be useful for other purposes as well, such as
954addressing limited and prolonged duration medical devices.
955The purpose of an exaggerated extraction is to produce an extractables profile which is at least
956as complete and complex as the worst-case leachables profile. This means that the exaggerated
957extractables minimally include all leachables, and that the levels of the exaggerated extractables
958meet or exceed the highest levels reached by leachables. An exaggerated extraction establishes in a
959single extraction the highest amount of extractables that most likely will be released by the medical
960device or material as leachables during clinical use. The exaggerated extraction is accomplished by
961using extraction conditions that are, in one or more dimensions, exaggerated versus the conditions of
962clinical use. For example, an exaggerated extraction might be performed considering one or more of the
963conditions below:
964—        At a temperature that exceeds the clinical use temperature (typically referred to as an accelerated
965extraction, see D.4);
966—        With a duration that exceeds the duration of clinical use;
967—        With a vehicle whose extraction power exceeds that of the solution that mediates the clinical contact
968between the medical device and potentially affected individual;
969—        At a surface area/volume ratio that exceed clinical use exposure;
970—        Via the use of exhaustive (sequential) extraction for limited or prolonged contact medical devices.
971Devising and justifying exaggerated extraction conditions can be a technically challenging exercise and
972great care should be taken to ensure that the scientific basis for the exaggerated conditions is rigorous
973and sound. Although certain exaggerating conditions can be appropriate and justifiable for certain
974situations, they might not be universally applicable to all situations.

982ISO 10993-18:2020(E)
983If an exaggerated extraction cannot be justified or experimentally verified, then its use for producing
984chemical information that is the basis of a toxicological risk assessment is not recommended.
985When an exaggerated extraction is employed, it is necessary to account for the exaggeration both in
986designing the extraction and in interpreting the result of the extraction study. One means of accounting
987for the exaggeration is via an exaggeration factor (a numerical factor that estimates the degree to
988which an exaggerated extraction amplifies the clinical conditions of use), although other means can
989be envisioned and employed. Regardless of the means, the degree of exaggeration is established by
990a rigorous assessment of the extraction and clinical use conditions and knowledge of the degree of
991exaggeration may be used to adjust the results of the exaggerated extraction to allow for the toxicological
992risk assessment of the extractables. Thus, for example, if quantity of extracted medical devices is
993doubled over that used clinically, or the device contact surface area to contact solution volume ratio of
994the extraction is doubled this degree of exaggeration should be taken into account when the extractables
995data are reported for toxicological risk assessment. It should be noted that greatly exaggerated surface
996area/solution volume ratios may not produce proportionally exaggerated extractables profiles, making
997an accounting of the degree of exaggeration more challenging. Furthermore, any quantification of
998degree of extraction exaggeration should address whether the extractables’ concentrations have
999reached an equilibrium-based plateau (i.e. that sink conditions have been maintained).
1000Due to the vast number of various medical devices and usage conditions within the scope of this
1001document, it is unrealistic to provide specific guidance here. However, points to consider in establishing
1002exaggerated conditions are outlined as follows.
1003Dimensions to consider when establishing and justifying an exaggerating extraction vehicle include
1004pH (for aqueous vehicles) and polarity (for organic or “organic-like” vehicles). Considering extraction
1005vehicle pH, it is noted that pH is an exaggerating dimension only for acidic or basic extractables (that is,
1006the extraction of neutral or un-ionisable extractables is largely unaffected by the pH of the extraction
1007vehicle). For acidic extractables (e.g. stearic acid), it is generally the case that an extraction vehicle with
1008a pH higher than that of the clinical contact solution will exaggerate extraction. For a basic extractable
1009(e.g. dibenzylamine), it is generally the case that an extraction vehicle with a pH lower than that of the
1010clinical contact solution will exaggerate extraction. A neutral extractable’s accumulation level will be
1011unaffected by pH unless that neutral compound is reactive as a function of pH.
1012For neutral extractables, extraction vehicle polarity can be an exaggerating dimension. For example,
1013increasing the alcohol content of an extraction vehicle versus the clinical contact solution will typically
1014result in an exaggerated extraction.
1015The use of temperature as an exaggerating dimension is addressed in D.4.
1016Exaggerated extraction conditions should not alter the extractables profile. For example, the use
1017of extreme temperatures as a means of accomplishing the exaggeration might result in either the
1018decomposition of the extractables or the alteration of the medical device materials (e.g. curing, cross-
1019linking, or degradation of the device’s polymeric materials of construction, physical state change over
1020the glass transition temperature), any of which could result in an altered extractables profile.
1021When extraction is exaggerated using multiple dimensions (e.g. both temperature and surface area),
1022the combined effect of the multiple dimensions should be considered and justified, although doing so
1023can be scientifically challenging.
1024As altered extractables profiles can be obtained when greatly exaggerated extraction conditions are
1025employed, it is recommended that exaggerations be kept as small as is necessary, minimizing potential
1026complicating effects such as degradation. As exaggeration is justified in the context of the circumstances
1027in which it is employed, determining whether an exaggeration is appropriate or excessive is done on a
1028case by case basis and it is difficult to provide general guidelines in terms of when an exaggeration
1029is no longer appropriate and becomes excessive. Nevertheless, highly exaggerated conditions can be
1030sufficiently extreme that the exaggerated extractables profile becomes poorly correlated with the
1031clinical use extractables profile. The justification of any exaggeration, but especially a significant
1032exaggeration should consider the exaggerated extraction’s propensity to chemically or physically alter
1033the test article and/or the extracted substances, as extractions that alter either the test article or the
1034extracted substances are not permitted.
